Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Operator Algebras and Ergodic Theory

POR.DRECONTENT:
My project focused on classification in Operator Algebras. To understand this, one can think of it as a type of geometry. In high school geometry one studies geometric figures by way of lengths and angles. In Operator Algebras one studies geometric objects, though usually not the same ones as studied in high school geometry, by way of their symmetries.

   For clarification, let us take an example. Consider two simple geometric shapes, a circle and a square. One can tell these apart by the symmetries. Specifically, a circle can be rotated by any angle and it will look the same. A square, on the other hand, can only be rotated by a few specific angles, otherwise the corners will not match up. Thus, one can say that a circle has more rotational symmetry that a square. This is the viewpoint of Operator Algebras. It uses symmetries of geometric objects to study and classify them.

    This point of view is important because of its application to Quantum Mechanics. In Quantum Mechanics, one often cannot observe objects directly. Instead one can only see how things change after particles collide with them. Thus knowing possible geometric configurations and symmetries of subatomic particles is vitally important, and a large motivation for research in Operator Algebras.

    My project focused on the connection between Operator Algebras and Ergodic Theory. One can view Ergodic Theory as the study of those symmetries of geometric objects that might change their shape, but do not change lengths, area, or other measurements of size. Think here of taking a square and cutting it into pieces and then rearranging them. In this case the shape will change, but the size will not.

    In my research I was able to, in certain circumstances, reconstruct the original geometric object, given the distorted "puzzle-like" picture coming from Ergodic Theory. The basic strategy was developed by my advisor, Sorin Popa, and comes under the term deformation/rigidity. The idea is to first locate certain parts that cannot be distorted very much, thus one can then know where these "go" and use this as a starting point to reconstruct the entire geometric picture.
